string_table.name: npxnsnfns1110001001
string_table.string: Skip Navigation. Hit enter to return to the slide.

slidetranscripts.slidetranscript:
Hi, I’m Maria. Welcome to the Introduction to DTE Energy course. The purpose of this course is to provide you with an overview of DTE as you start your new role here.

It provides a look at some highlights from DTE’s history, our aspiration, purpose, priorities, and values, as well as our business and our commitment to our employees and our community.

This course contains four modules.

When you’re in a module, you can click the Next button to view the next screen or Previous button to view a previous screen.

There are extras available to you as well…an explanation of how electricity is made, gas is stored, and more. To access them, click the Extras link at any time.

Also, we’ve included ten bonus content facts about DTE for you to find throughout the course. Just look for the flag icon. When you find one, click it to reveal the fact.

Start out by clicking one of the four circuit breakers to switch it on and learn more about that topic. We recommend that you start with our history, but you can complete the modules in any order you choose.

Hi, I’m Joe and I’ve been with DTE for almost 30 years. During that time I’ve seen a lot of changes. We didn't start on this journey yesterday... DTE Energy has a proud history, reflecting more than 150 years of innovation and service.

Here’s a look of some of the highlights from DTE’s history.

In 1849, MichCon was founded as the Detroit City as Light Company.
In 1886, Detroit Edison began as the Edison Illuminating Company.
In 1908, Detroit City Gas Company went public.

Between 1924 and 1929, to keep up with the booming population in Detroit, the Marysville, Trenton Channel, and Delray 3 Power Plants were added. To support the skyscraper boom in downtown Detroit, Beacon and Boulevard heating plants were added.
In 1926, the ticker symbol on Wall Street changed to DTE.

From 1941 to 1945, automakers converted their plants to support military efforts. Michigan provided 92% of aircraft bombs, 75% of the aircraft engines, and 56% of the tanks used by American military forces. MichCon and Detroit Edison worked around the clock to supply energy needed by these factories to support the war effort.
In 1956, Detroit Edison broke ground for the Enrico Fermi atomic power plant - the world's first. The River Rouge Power Plant was also added.
In 1957, introduced first computer generated customer bills.
In 1980, computer technology led to automated meter reading.
In 1986, the Detroit Edison Foundation was established to manage the company's charitable giving programs and volunteer efforts.
During the 1990s, deregulation occurred, allowing customers to choose their own electric company.
In 1996, DTE Energy Holding Co. was founded.
In 2001, MichCon and DTE Energy merged, forming the state's largest full-service energy provider.

In 2009, an economic downturn hit the nation. As a company committed to Southeastern Michigan, the company stepped up its Continuous Improvement efforts to gain cost efficiencies and reductions, allowing it to keep workforce intact and meet its financial goals.

Also in 2009, the Michigan Legislature passed PA 295, which mandated that a 10% Renewable Portfolio Standard be accomplished by 2015. At DTE, electricity from renewable resources - wind, sunlight and biomass - plays an important role in meeting our customers’ energy needs while reducing our environmental footprint.
In 2013, Detroit Edison was renamed DTE Electric and MichCon was renamed DTE Gas.

Throughout the course, we’ll stop for checkpoints. Here, we’ll either ask you questions about what you’ve learned or ask you to think about and document your thoughts around the topic we’ve just covered.

In this first checkpoint, let’s see if you can place these events from DTE’s history in the correct decade. Don’t worry…we don’t expect you to remember what year the events took place, just see if you can put them in perspective by dragging them under the appropriate decade. When you’ve placed each event, click Done

That completes the DTE History module. In it, you saw some of the highlights from DTE’s long history. We are a company with a rich past, and we continue to look forward to a prosperous future.

Click Next to return to the circuit breaker room.
Welcome back. Select another module to continue learning more about DTE.
Great job, you’ve completed another module. Select another module to continue learning more about DTE.
You’ve finished three of the modules. Select the remaining module to continue learning more about DTE.
Nice work, you’ve completed all four modules. Click Next to go to the course wrap up.

Hi, I’m Bayley. I’ve been a customer service representative at DTE for two years. One of the reasons I was excited to start my job here is because I wanted to work for a company that makes it a priority to have highly engaged employees. It’s important to me to feel like I am a part of making the company successful.

DTE Energy has established an “operating system” that describes what the company wants to achieve strategically, where it will focus it’s efforts, and how we will behave as we work together to be successful. All of these elements are shown together in a graphic we call “The Big Picture,” which includes our Aspiration, Corporate Priorities, Values, Capabilities, and Purpose. Together, these elements comprise DTE’s Operating System. Each element points toward our Aspiration; to better understand this, let’s look at each element more closely.

Aspiration: Our Aspiration describes what we want to be. We want to be the best operated energy company in North America and a force for growth and prosperity in the communities where we live and serve.

Corporate Priorities: Our corporate priorities help us focus on the right things. There are six corporate priorities within this integrated system. These priorities guide is on “how” we’ll achieve our aspiration.

Values: Our values provide “guide rails” as we journey toward achieving our aspiration. They provide context and “connection” for our people and describe behaviors that we strive to demonstrate every day.

Foundational Capabilities: We have identified 9 areas of “capability” that describe those things we need to be really good at to be successful. These capabilities are key to achieving our aspiration.

Purpose: Our purpose is how we connect and impact the world.

Now that you’ve heard about DTE’s Operating System, let’s take a closer look at our Purpose.

DTE’s purpose is “We serve with our energy, the lifeblood of communities and the engine of progress.”

Select each highlighted word to learn more about what it means to DTE.

Now that you know our purpose, let’s look at our aspiration…where DTE is heading.

Our aspiration is to be the best-operated energy company in North America and a force for growth and prosperity in the communities where we live and serve.

The company has defined six corporate priorities that describe how we are going to achieve our aspiration. These priorities provide the framework for DTE Energy’s business plan - the strategy by which we are moving from our current state toward our aspiration. Each day, every employee plays a role in putting our Corporate System of Priorities into action. Targets in each priority area are identified and communicated each year. These targets define our annual goals.

Select each priority to learn more about it.

Our foundational capabilities are the abilities, skills, and knowledge we all need to contribute to our corporate priorities and achieve our aspiration. All of them are supported by a robust system of learning so that all employees have the opportunity to increase their capability in any of these areas.

So, we’ve just briefly talked about our purpose, aspiration, corporate priorities, and foundational capabilities; next, let's talk about the rest of the big picture - our values.

We are what we repeatedly do. And that’s why how we make the journey matters. How we conduct ourselves with one another. How we make decisions in “moments of truth and trade-off.” And how we work together to get things done.

As we accelerate our progress toward our aspiration, our values serve as “rules of the road.” They are how DTE Energy thinks and acts.

Our values only have real power if we routinely live them, act on them―and do so with conviction.

We need to remember that, “Our values are not a poster on the wall or words on a plaque. They are something inside us-something we carry with us as we interact with each other, with our customers, with anyone who knows us and sees us as DTE Energy. This ‘soft stuff’ actually is the ‘hard stuff’."

Let’s take a closer look at our values to help you better understand them as you begin your role at DTE.

We’ll start with health and safety. We put the health and safety of people first, and know this responsibility rests with each of us. That bears repeating…the responsibility of putting people’s health and safety first rests with each of us.

We are the lifeblood of communities and the engine of progress. That’s why we do what we do each day. But we never forget that for many of our people this is dangerous work. So in a company like ours, with a long history of focusing on safety, we believe diligence is vital. That’s why we embrace the principle of 200 percent accountability. This includes the environment— we are dedicated to protecting our employees, neighbors and the environment around us, to make sure we minimize our impact.

We believe that improvement is our daily responsibility, and know those we serve have the right to expect that from us.

Our daily focus on continuous improvement sets the stage for operational excellence. We can’t just show up and work in our business, we all have a responsibility to work, on our business, finding new and better ways to get things done and deliver value to our customers and communities. Each of us expects the products and services we buy from other companies to improve over time, our customers have the right to expect the same from us.

We act with integrity and show respect, and understand this defines our company's character,

Integrity is about approaching our business with honesty, ethics, and full transparency. We are committed to integrity and being completely forthright in everything we do. And as for respect, we believe it's something everyone at DTE Energy deserves. The rule of thumb that we live and work by is to show a high level of respect and consideration for, our fellow employees, customers, suppliers, contractors, and neighbors. To do otherwise is not the "DTE Energy Way."

We play to win as a team, and put the needs of our enterprise first.

Our work is interconnected. That’s why we need to work together, respecting our individuality and differences while we pursue a common cause In order to perform as one team, we strive to be crystal clear about responsibilities, handoffs, and interdependencies. It’s about collaborating across boundaries to find new and better ways to get things done.

We see our work through the eyes of those we serve, and know that our work is a powerful means to serve others. We must provide the kind of service that we’d like to receive if we were the customer. This challenges us to look at the ways we’re carrying out our work and ask, “If I could view my work through the eyes of my customers, would I be proud of the way that I’m doing it?”

We bring our best energy and focus to our work, and are fully engaged and accountable for results. The work we do is vitally important to the people, companies and communities we serve. As a result, how well each of us does our job matters. We believe that an engaged workforce is the key to our success, and work together to identify opportunities to enable high levels of engagement for all.

We are passionate about the success of our company, and know that its health and growth generate prosperity. Vibrant, healthy and growing companies help our society and economy to thrive. So one of the best things each of us can do for our communities is to make sure that our company is healthy and strong.

Now that you have a better understanding of DTE’s operating system, it’s time for another checkpoint.

Drag each item to the DTE value statement that it completes; then click Done.

You’ve just completed DTE’s Operating System module. In it, you learned how our purpose, aspiration, foundational capabilities, and corporate priorities and values are all connected.

Click Next to return to the circuit breaker room.

Hi, I’m David. I’ve been at DTE for 18 years.

At DTE, we’re passionate about the growth of our company. So, as you start your new role, it’s important for you to understand some key aspects of our business.

Here’s a look at our company and its parts. For more than 150 years, we have served the homes and businesses of Michigan with reliable and affordable electric and natural gas services. We have also leveraged that wealth of experience and assets to develop a number of non-utility subsidiaries that provide energy-related services to businesses and industries nationwide. Select each part of our business to learn more.

Every employee who works at DTE Energy, even those who do not interact directly with customers, contributes to the customers' experience of our company and their satisfaction with our products and services. As an employee of DTE Energy, you are likely a customer as well, and also live and are active in a community of DTE Energy customers. You have a unique opportunity to create positive customer experiences with your neighbors and friends and family. By knowing about the company programs and ways to help our customers resolve problems, you become a DTE Ambassador.

Our customer-focused efforts across the company are moving us towards our goal to be number one in customer satisfaction across electric and gas service providers as we journey to our aspiration to be the best-operated energy company in North America. That’s no easy feat, but with the dedication and inspiration of all our employees, we are on the road to success.

We know our customers' expectations are changing, and so must we.

Select each image to learn how we leverage technology to improve our customer experience:

• Programs such as eBill and Budget Wise Billing that provide added ease and convenience for our customers

• Customer 360, which is revamping our business and financial systems to ensure a seamless experience for our customers

• Developing our Advanced Meter Infrastructure (AMI)

• Building digital channels for customers to conduct business with us in their channel of choice like the DTE Energy Mobile app, Payment Kiosks, and through improvements to the DTE Energy website.

• Energy Efficiency apps so customer are empowered to plan and manage their energy costs

Depending on your role, you may be interacting directly with our customers, or you may be an important part of our “Customer Value Chain” providing support and working to ensure that each of us do what we can to reduce costs, eliminate defects, provide excellent service, and support our community. All of these actions contribute to our customer’s experience with our company.
Watch a video to hear about one of our latest initiatives to meet and exceed our customer’s expectations.

DTE Energy is a Fortune 300 company and the largest electric and natural gas utility in Michigan. We are a publically-traded, investor-owned company headquartered in Detroit, Michigan.

Although DTE Energy is most strongly associated with Michigan, you may be surprised to learn that we operate nationwide. In fact, DTE Energy employs nearly 10,000 people, operates in 550 communities throughout Michigan.

Let’s stop for another checkpoint.

Who regulates the rates DTE Energy charges for electricity and gas? Type your answer in the box; then click Done.

You’ve completed the Our Business module. In it, you learned about DTE’s service areas and locations, our utility and non-utility businesses, and learned about our commitment to our customers. Want to learn more about how Gas and Electricity are produced and delivered to our customers? Check out the links in the Extras section.

Click Next to return to the circuit breaker room.
Hi, I’m Miguel. I’ve been at DTE for 6 years. Throughout that time, I’ve seen that DTE is committed to our employees and our community.

At DTE Energy, our employees are the foundation of our company and the energy behind our operations. Employee engagement remains one of DTE’s six priority areas and is the key enabler and driver to achieving our other priorities.

When it comes to employee engagement, the Gallup organization places DTE Energy among the most elite organizations in the world, and has awarded DTE Energy the coveted “Great WorkPlace Award" for four straight years, beginning in 2013.

Highly engaged employees start with employees that come to work each day ready to give their best… who know that safety is their top priority…and who are eager to learn and share what they know with each other. This is fundamental.

With an engaged team, we can make a powerful difference in the lives of the millions of customers we serve.

For all DTE Employees, knowing what is expected is a key to high engagement. How we all treat one another and are expected to go about our work is detailed in something that we call the "DTE Energy Way".

DTE Energy has a long and rich history of working to create a diverse workforce and inclusive working environment. We believe diversity is about ensuring that all employees feel valued and included. It's about understanding and embracing our unique differences, talents and perspectives. By making a commitment to diversity, we are making a commitment to all employees and to the success of our business.

We understand that our workplace, the communities we serve and our region encompass a broad mix of individuals with diverse backgrounds, cultures and experiences. Learning to embrace these differences, recognizing their inherent strengths and working together are essential to building strong communities.

At DTE, we value diversity and inclusion. One way we show this is by encouraging our employees to share their experiences, ideas, and opinions openly in Employee Resource Network Group (ERNG) which center on common bonds. Women of DTE and the African American Action Association are a couple examples of current ERNGs.

Volunteerism is one of the ways we demonstrate our purpose and it’s an important aspect of the DTE culture. Each year, thousands of DTE Energy employees volunteer in their neighborhoods and the communities we serve, lending a helping hand to hundreds of deserving organizations. DTE Care Force provides organized enterprise-wide volunteer opportunities, including our signature events such as Meals on Wheels and Month of Caring, as well as more “skill-based” opportunities to bring your specific knowledge and skills to communities in a sustainable and meaningful way.

Community outreach is important to us, and we show this by committing our time to help out in the communities we serve.

At DTE Energy, we put the safety and health of our employees and customers first. DTE’s commitment to safety is about ensuring our employees and our customers are safe every day. We work to keep our employees safe with training, safety huddles, Personal Protective Equipment for all work, and more. We’re concerned about the health and safety of our customers and communities. One example of this is our Secure First team - made up of DTE Energy employees trained in procedures that help protect the public from potentially hazardous wires.

When a storm hits, DTE Energy goes into action to ensure that our customers remain safe while power is being restored. Your role during a storm may be actually guarding down wires or other assignments that keep things going during a storm, ensuring our customers are safe, and we are able to restore power as quickly as possible.

Protecting the public is a vital service our employees provide to customers and communities during storms and is a key way that we live our safety core value as a company.

You’ve completed the Our Employees and Community module. In it, you learned that highly engaged employees are fundamental to our success. We value diversity and recognize its importance to our success. We are committed to our community. Community outreach is important to us and we show it by our actions. We are committed to the safety of our employees, customers, and communities.

Click Next to return to the circuit breaker room.

DTE’s commitment to safety is about ensuring our employees and our customers are safe every day. With a special focus on Life Critical Standards we want to drive a heightened awareness on safety requirements when working in a high-risk environment, and ensure all employees and our customers are aware of the hazards that can be life threatening.

Select each Life Critical Standard to learn more.
Given our focus on Life Critical Standards, take a minute to see if you can match each Life Critical Standard to its description.

Congratulations! You’ve completed the DTE Onboarding Web Overview Course. In it, you learned about DTE’s history, and saw DTE’s Operating System, which shows how we can work towards achieving our aspiration. You also learned more about our business in general, and our commitment to our employees and the communities we serve.

Before we talk about next steps…did you find all of the bonus content that was hidden? If not, don’t worry. Click the bonus content link to see a list of the bonus content and what screen it was hidden on.

So, what’s next?

First, take a moment to reflect on what you’ve just learned, and jot down any notes or questions for follow up with your leader or others. If you’d like a certificate of completion, you can print one by clicking “print”.

Congratulations! You’ve completed an important step in your process of getting to know the great company DTE is, and readying yourself for the start of a great career.

To exit the course, select the Close button in your browser.

Electricity

Electricity is produced, or generated, at a power plant that is fueled by either coal or nuclear energy. But when it is produced, it can’t be readily delivered to the customer since, the voltage is too high. So, there are a number of interim steps.

Once the electricity is produced at the plant, it is pushed out over a transmission system (or the large towers that you see in large open fields or along major boulevards) for delivery to large stations. The transmission system can carry up to 345 kilovolts of current over the system.

Once the electricity is received at the station, it is “stepped down,” or the voltage is reduced, to a level where the electricity can be delivered over a sub-transmission system which can carry either 120, 40, or 24 kilovolts of current. This voltage is then delivered to a “substation” where, once again, the voltage is stepped down to a level that can be carried over a “distribution system.”

The distribution system is the system of lines that carry electricity to the customer’s service lines. These lines can carry anywhere from 4.8 kilovolts to 13.2 kilovolts of electric current and eventually are hooked up to a customer’s service lines by an overhead service or underground service.

Gas

The natural gas is removed from the ground in the gas field and moved to a storage facility via a pipeline. These pipelines are part of the gas “transmission system.” The pipelines used in the gas system, like the lines carrying electricity, are sized, but the sizes in the gas system depend on the amount of pressure being used to move the gas. So, when moving from the field to the storage facility, the pipelines are larger, and they generally decrease in size as you move down the system.

From the storage facility, the gas is moved to a compressor station where any loss in pressure that is experienced during the movement from the storage facility is recovered.

The gas is then sent on its way further down the transmission system to gate stations where the gas pressure is reduced (similar to electrical current being stepped down).

At the gate stations, the gas has moved into the distribution system for delivery to customers.

There may be other stops along the distribution system for regulation of gas pressure, depending on the service territory being served. But basically, from the gate station, the gas goes to the customer – residential, commercial, or industrial.
